Enterprise Disintegration Antipatterns On the Road with PaaS

.

Study Failure

Software fails, and the cost of failure extremely high. Fight failure successfully and you’ll save bigtime. But how does one fight failure? The answer is simple: Study it.

This sounds about as exciting as a Six Sigma class, but it turns out it’s actually quite fascinating. After a while, patterns emerge. These patterns represent bad choices that end up costing a fortune, and are best avoided.

We all know that the real reason it’s fun to study failure is the overwhelming sense of relief that comes from knowing that some other poor sap had to go through this, and NOT ME!

Anyway I’m calling these patterns Enterprise Disintegration Antipatterns since they affect corporations of all sizes, they have damaging (disintegrating) consequences, and therefore like all antipatterns, should be avoided.

Without a solid foundation the enterprise will disintegrate

   An Enterprise Disintegration Antipattern is any repeated
   behavior that tends towards failure of enterprise software or
   enterprise software organizations.

Ed note: it still sounds mind-numbinginly boring See SIDEBAR How much does this cost? See SIDEBAR What is an antipattern?

The good news is that with a solid foundation, many/most of these patterns can be avoided.

This series follows a pattern itself, which is to:

  1. Identify and describe a common antipattern

  2. Identify likely causes

  3. Describe how issue can be avoided using PaaS

  4. Summarize cost to implement (tco)

  5. Summary total value/gain

This blog series highlights that that tends towards a less desirable result. It turns out antipatterns are rampant in enterprise software development. Whether large or small, established or startup, failure, failure happens.

AntiPattern One: Optimize early

This is one of the most tantelizing, seductive, and … nefarious antipatterns. In fact avoiding it is one of the harder engineering problems. Well, hardest engineer problems anyway.

Consider this O(n4): Problem: documents with words , find … who knows. but this should be easy. Scenerio:

for .. for for for end

You know - it’s SO tempting to spend a few minutes fixing this. But don’t.

WHY: Five reasons:

  1. it’s probably fast already

  2. it’s probably fast enough

  3. faster usually more complex (engineer time vs. cpu time)

3a. optimization often leads to obfuscation

  1. requirements change

  2. your time can be MUCH better spent

Just Say No!

This is really hard to do: it’s such a blast to take an method, algorithm, whole application, and Make It FFFaast.

Many software engineerings thrive on this alone.

But… resist Resitance Is Infutile.

Instead of opgimizing: WRITE TESTS!

More generally, measure the performance in a repeatable way. Use tests or tools or process, whatever you like, just make sure it can be repeated.

I.e., trade the 15 minutes (400 hours) you would have spent optimizing the above code for testing time. Set up a test process, research tools, fiddle around with rspec/cucumber/selenium, stand up from your cubicle and yell TEST to everyone within hearing distance.

Bottom line: Test, don’t optimize. This is a general theme of this series.

But how is this relevant here?

If you’re reading this magazine chances are you’re well versed in the various “Premature Optimization discussions” triggured decades Dr Dobbs Readers know this already. Premature Optimization has long been eschewed by engineering best practices. And testing is, after a long arduous journey, finally becoming mainstream.

But pre-omptimization is almost always thought of as tweaking code to make it faster. There are other aspedts of premature optimization that aren’t so obvious, or cut and dry.
